label: Letter from Gertrude Sanford Legendre, March 24, 1944
description: Letter from Gertrude Legendre to her husband, Sidney Legendre, regarding her social life in London, England, a cocktail party she hosted, and reminiscing on times past they had spent together.

metadata.label: Transcript

R 4 6 44
March 24, '44
Dear Sidney,
This is one of those mornings that drives one
absolutely crazy to be cooped up inside. Its clear and bright
and brisk with such a tang of spring in the air it drives you
crazy. There's a peach tree breking into bloom that I pass on
my way to the office[,]and I would give allthe world to be in the
country.
That wonderful Inn I described is now full up in-
definately[,]and I think I made a huge mistake not to engagea room
by the season so I could go down week ends and play golf. Every-
think - everywhere is booked and particularly over Easter. As
all the south is closed off to travel I presume it makes even
more people trying ot get in elsewhere. I guess I must resign
myself to the city till the war is over. Lord I hate it too
now that the light is long and the evening delicious. I do so
envy you your scenery, your air, your sea and your flowers.
I shall no doubt stew and grown with that burning desire to
be out of doors from now on till the end of summer. Cest la
vie! Cest la guerre! The fun of setting up the office, starting
a new desk etc. etc has all worn off. The whole thing is such
routine it lacks stimulous. Its nearly the end of the seventh
month now that I have been here and I want new worlds to
conquer. I have n't a prayer of a change for ages and I hope
it is doing my soul good to be so rigidly disciplines and
grouved. I am afraid however it does it no good at all- rather
dulls and flattens me out, puts lines in the face, fat on the
bones,and a jaded look in the eye. All my bones crack when I 
move, and my spine creeks at eve[r]y vertabraie[sp?].
I had chinese foodat a chinese restaurant yesterday[,]
and then went to see a collection of paintings nearby. Every
painting was sold although the exhibition had only been on two
days. Christie's is selling the Morgan collection here and the
prices that it is fetching are fantastic. Antiques and jewelry
and silver[,]have never been higher. Its quite amazing. By afternoon
so fast inside as rice and chopsuey. It has no staying powerat
all[,]and one finds one self very hungry by three o'clock.
Olive has sent me some New Orleans soup- crawfish bisque- which 
I am thrilled with.You remember how er fooled Marshal Field on it.?
I also have some canned breasts of turkey Rose sent me,so to-night
after the theatre I am going ot feast Alfred [illegible] and his beautiful
bride on a very sumptuous dinner.My parcels from home are a god
send, just makes all the difference.
I had a very amusing time the other day. Marian Hall
a wonderful girl [Red Cross Executive here] lunched with me. She
[End Page 1]
2
She had received a case of whiskey some time a go from Lehman Bro.
N.Y. via their Overseas contact. Marian cut the tag off the case
and suggested we trot around to this source of supply and see what
we could do. We gave the address to the taxi driver and he started
of. We went miles, and I mean miles, to hell and gone into the
suburbs and finally landed up up 25 minutes later in front of a ware[-]
house. We went in and asked for the Manager. Hewwas found in a dingy
cold office wrapped in an over coat and muffler, peering over his
ledgers. He was fat and wore glasses on the end of his nose. Marian
went right to the point. Said we were two thirsty Amwricans looking
for gin and whiskey. He listened for a bit and then said he had never
heard of either of us and did n't know who we were, and did not see
why we had not gone to the city office instead of the ware house.
From here on we did our stuf. We said we always went to the source
of supply, that their American Agents were our pals, we did some
hand across the sea, anglo-American relations talk etc etc. and e[nded]
up with each of us with a goblet of straight gin in our hands[,]and
drinking toasts to each other. I never ha[d] more of a laugh. Itowe
was two o'clock in the afternoon, we had eaten a big lunch, and here
we were tossing [gin] down ur throats like straight vodka- in order
to make our purchase. It ended up by a phone call to the home office[,]
and each of us going home with a case of gin a piece in the taxi.
[no whiskey however as that is even rarer and more difficult]. It
was a successful trip and we did have a laugh. On the strength of
this acquisition I gave a cocktail party last Saturday and had
about 18 people. To my amazement only 2 [a half] bottles were consumed
and everyone seemed to have plenty. It was great fun. Most of my
office pals were the guests[,]with some Red Cross gals mixed in.
I had Dorothy and Anthony Head for dinner the other day. Do you
remember the day we motored her to the Shonnards and you made up with
the Ashly and Cooper River. They are awfully nice. He is one of the
youngest Brigadier Generals in the Br. army I believe, and charming
too.
I miss Ben very much. The old Cornel and I used to lunch often
together at Bucks and talk over old times. I doubt if he gets back
again now.
I shall be very old next week[,]and I think I shall county my
grey hairs that day for I am sure I have at least 42 of them.
I had a letter from Janie dated August '43. She said s[c]heeing
had been such fun in the hills with freinds, that their apartment
was so beautiful, that as it was hot they were soon going ot the sea
as they had just bought a house on a beach, etc etc, The old 
usual happy picture of a tr[a]nquil life- one month before invasion.
So typical! I wonder if she still feels so peaceful?
The war stretches on and on ispite of all this super bombing,
but I suppose it must end some day. It cant go on for ever. When
that's the question?
I do get Life and Time now even though very late, but I
love them as they really give you a picture than in no other way
one gets.Have you read a book called"So Little Time!?You must get
it.Its tops, by the same man who wrote Pulham Esq.
Raymond has two big Tanny Spanials in the country,and he is
going to find me a fat cream and white spanial soon.
Please give my love to all your Brothers.I know you are
having agreat time together-
Love-
Gertrude Legendre
[End Page 2]
